title: The Ultimate Guide to Taking Care of Permed Hair

steps.title: Avoid washing your hair for the first 48 to 72 hours.
steps.content: Avoid washing your hair for the first 48 to 72 hours. After you get a perm, avoid shampooing or conditioning your hair for the first 48 to 72 hours. As Foster explains, the best way to maintain the look of a perm is “to avoid water.” [1] X Expert Source Courtney Foster Professional Hair Stylist Expert Interview. 9 December 2019. Water can deactivate your perm and make the curls fall apart. [2] X Research source Make sure to keep your hair as dry as possible, especially if it’s raining or snowing outside. Ask your stylist how long you should wait until washing your hair. The length of time may depend on your hair and type of perm. If you absolutely can’t wait to wash your hair, call your stylist to find out the best way to handle the situation. They may suggest using dry shampoo or another product. With this, also avoid swimming for 72 hours and getting your hair wet in a pool or hot tub for 7 days, as the chemicals can loosen your new curls. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Wear your hair loose and avoid clip-in accessories for the first 48 hours.
steps.content: Wear your hair loose and avoid clip-in accessories for the first 48 hours. Even after you leave the salon, your hair and perm will still be settling. Because of this, it’s important to wear your hair down or in loose hairstyles to prevent the curls from misshaping. Avoid ponytails, braids, and clips for a few days after your perm. [4] X Research source Use a silk scarf to gently pull back your hair if necessary. Make sure to tie it as loosely as possible to keep your hair back without leaving a mark. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Touch your hair sparingly during the first 48 hours.
steps.content: Touch your hair sparingly during the first 48 hours. After you get a perm, playing with your new curls or waves may be tempting. But do your best to avoid touching your hair. It can take 24 to 48 hours for the curls to lock in place, and touching your hair could loosen them. Leaving your hair be for a couple of days can help ensure that your hair maintains its shape for longer. [6] X Research source Also, your hair is incredibly fragile after getting a perm. Not touching or playing with your hair can also help prevent unnecessary breakage. Use your fingers to style your hair only as necessary during this time, and avoid brushing or combing your hair.

steps.title: Stay away from color treatments during the first week.
steps.content: Stay away from color treatments during the first week. Keep in mind that permed hair can be fragile and needs a lot of love, especially in the first week after a perm. Avoid getting color treatments on your hair for 3 to 7 days after your perm. This way, you can avoid causing further stress or damage and prevent your hair from breaking off. [7] X Research source Talk to your stylist about scheduling a color treatment within a safe time frame from your perm. Consider using a hair tint, colored powder, or color shampoo instead of color treatments, as they’re much safer on your hair. Remember that even if you wait at least a week to color your hair, you may still experience breakage.

steps.title: Use products formulated for permed or fragile hair moving forward.
steps.content: Use products formulated for permed or fragile hair moving forward. No matter what, permed hair needs special and gentle aftercare. Getting specially formulated products can restore luster to stressed and fragile permed hair. In addition, they can help maintain your curls for a longer period of time. Look for product labels with ingredients such as biotin, eucalyptus oil, and soy and are labeled as “for permed hair” or “for chemically treated hair.” Foster also recommends avoiding products that contain parabens and sulfates to help your perm last. [8] X Expert Source Courtney Foster Professional Hair Stylist Expert Interview. 9 December 2019. When in doubt, ask your stylist for product suggestions!

steps.title: Shampoo your hair weekly after getting your perm.
steps.content: Shampoo your hair weekly after getting your perm. Cleaning your hair can keep your curls fresh and bouncy. But washing it too often can strip your already delicate hair of essential oils and make your perm relax faster. Treat your permed hair like silk or another delicate fabric: washing it once a week is enough to keep it clean and help maintain its beauty. [9] X Research source Wash your hair with warm water, as hot water can dry out your curls. [10] X Research source Always use a sulfate-free shampoo to help minimize frizz and strengthen your hair. [11] X Research source Make sure to thoroughly rinse with warm or cool water, as lingering residue can weigh your curls down. [12] X Research source Try using dry shampoo on your roots in between washes to keep your hair looking fresh. [13] X Research source Consider using a hair mask after shampooing to give your hair an added boost of moisture.

steps.title: Condition your hair after washing once the perm has settled.
steps.content: Condition your hair after washing once the perm has settled. Even the gentlest perm can strip hair of moisture, making it look dull and frizzy. Foster describes that some say conditioner relaxes a perm, but that’s not the case. Conditioner formulated for permed hair restores moisture and helps your perm last longer. [14] X Expert Source Courtney Foster Professional Hair Stylist Expert Interview. 9 December 2019. So, never skip conditioner after shampooing to help detangle and keep your curls looking fresh. Apply conditioner to your ends first, and then work up to the base of your neck. Try combing your wet hair using a wide-tooth comb while the conditioner is still in it to help disperse the product and minimize hair breakage. [15] X Research source Rinse your hair thoroughly with warm water to ensure all the product is washed off. [16] X Research source Consider using leave-in conditioning treatments if your hair is very dry or stressed.

steps.title: Use a wide-toothed comb over a brush moving forward.
steps.content: Use a wide-toothed comb over a brush moving forward. Detangle your hair carefully with a wide-toothed comb after you’ve finished washing and rinsing your hair. Avoid brushing your hair altogether, and only comb your hair when necessary, as brushing and excessive combing can cause breakage and frizziness. Instead, simply comb until tangles are removed, or separate tangles with your fingers. [17] X Research source Make sure the teeth of your comb are spaced widely apart so that your curls are not split into little pieces that may frizz.

steps.title: Sleep on a silk pillowcase to protect your hair at night.
steps.content: Sleep on a silk pillowcase to protect your hair at night. Believe it or not, your standard cotton pillowcase isn’t the best for your new curly hair. Cotton absorbs moisture, and the friction it creates with your hair at night can cause breakage and frizziness. To avoid this, switch to a silk pillowcase, as the silk material doesn’t absorb moisture and is gentler on your curls. [18] X Research source Try wrapping your hair up in a silk hair wrap at night for even more protection against frizz and damage.

steps.title: Trim your hair regularly.
steps.content: Trim your hair regularly. Your hair will continue to grow, and the extra weight can weigh down your curls. Foster recommends getting regular trims to help keep your curls bouncy and your hair healthy. [19] X Expert Source Courtney Foster Professional Hair Stylist Expert Interview. 9 December 2019. See your stylist every 4-6 weeks for a trim. Ask your stylist to trim the bare minimum if you’re concerned about losing length. Your stylist may even tell you you can wait longer between trims.

steps.title: Scrunch your hair daily.
steps.content: Scrunch your hair daily. The best way to keep your curls bouncy and looking fresh is to scrunch them with your fingers. Simply use your hands and fingers to gently lift and scrunch up individual sections of your hair. Mist your hair with water and hold for a few seconds to better define your curls. This beauty basic can enhance your new style and create soft, sultry waves. [20] X Research source You can also define individual curls by wrapping them around one or two fingers and holding them for a few seconds.

steps.title: Dry your hair naturally or with a diffuser.
steps.content: Dry your hair naturally or with a diffuser . A hairdryer can sap moisture from any person’s hair. But if you have permed hair, it can damage already stressed hair and make it frizzy. Either allow your hair to air dry or put a diffuser on your blow dryer to help define and protect your curls. Set your hair dryer on the coolest setting possible for the least damage.

steps.title: Use heat tools sparingly.
steps.content: Use heat tools sparingly. Curling and flat irons can damage your hair and cause it to break. After your perm, your hair is fragile and is more prone to breakage, so avoid heat tools whenever possible. Instead, try using steam to your benefit. Wrap your hair in a few rollers and put on a shower cap. Then, get in the shower and let the steam from the warm water reactivate your curls.

While perms can look super cute, they can come with their fair share of challenges—as with any hairstyle or cut. But don’t worry! These challenges can easily be avoided and remedied with a bit of practice and knowledge. Here are the most common issues you may face after getting your first perm: Uneven curls: Some sections may look uneven compared to others, especially when you’re just learning to style your curls. Style your hair with a diffuser in small sections, using a curl product , like mousse or gel, to keep your curls bouncy. [21] X Research source Frizziness: Curly hair (especially chemically treated curly hair) is prone to frizz. Avoid brushing your hair and touching it too much. You can also use frizz-reducing hair products to help tame your curls. Scalp irritation: Your head may be a bit sore after getting your perm due to the chemicals. Do your best to avoid scratching your scalp, and apply unscented aloe vera or an ice pack to the irritated area. [22] X Research source If you ever have any concerns about your perm or hair, reach out to your stylist for personalized advice!

steps.title: Perms can last for anywhere from 6 weeks to 8 months.
steps.content: Perms can last for anywhere from 6 weeks to 8 months. Caring for your perm will maintain it longer; however, once your curls start to fall apart and you have a lot of visible roots, you’ll likely need to get another perm. [23] X Research source Consider only getting your roots re-permed so your other hair doesn’t get too damaged. Talk to your stylist about your best options. If you decide you want to grow out your perm , you can do it without much headache. Caring for your hair with special products and little heat can keep it looking good during in-between stages.

steps.title: Yes, you can condition your hair 48 to 72 hours after getting it.
steps.content: Yes, you can condition your hair 48 to 72 hours after getting it. When you first get your perm, avoid water and washing at all costs to allow the chemicals to settle in your hair. After at least 48 hours, you can wash and condition your hair as normal. Curly hair tends to be drier than other hair types, so experts recommend conditioning regularly to maintain your curls and minimize frizz. [24] X Research source Consider using a leave-in conditioner on top of conditioning your hair in the shower to help combat frizz and keep your curls soft.

steps.title: A perm is a chemical hair treatment that alters your hair’s texture to be curlier.
steps.content: A perm is a chemical hair treatment that alters your hair’s texture to be curlier. There are two kinds of perms: cold and digital perms. A cold perm is when a stylist wraps the hair in rollers or rods and applies a chemical solution. A digital perm is when the stylist wraps the hair in warm rollers before applying the solution. No matter what perm you get, the hair will come out curlier or wavy, chemically altering your hair’s natural texture. [25] X Research source The size and thickness of the rollers or rods determine the overall size of the curls. Depending on the thickness of the hair, a perm can take 1 to 2 hours to complete. Perms can be done on all hair types! However, it’s the healthiest for those with hair that’s never been dyed or chemically treated.
